{{Refimprove|date=September 2008}} [[Image:HKBuildingFengshui.jpg|thumb|right|200px|A building in [[Hong Kong]] with a hollow middle hole, maximizing on [[fengshui]] prescriptions.]]
In the study of religion, '''orthopraxy''' is correct conduct, both [[ethical]] and [[liturgical]], as opposed to [[faith]] or [[Divine grace|grace]] etc.<ref>{{cite book |last=Jackson |first=Elizabeth |title=The Illustrated Dictionary of Culture |publisher=Lotus Press |year=2007 |isbn=978-81-89093-26-6 |pages= 147}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Westley |first=Miles |title=The Bibliophile's Dictionary |publisher=Writer's Digest Books |year=2005 |pages=91 |isbn=978-1-58297-356-2}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=McKim |first=Donald K. |title=Westminster Dictionary of Theological Terms |publisher=Westminster John Knox Press |year=1996 |pages=197 |isbn=978-0-664-25511-4}}</ref> This contrasts with [[orthodoxy]], which emphasizes correct belief, and [[wikt:ritualism|ritualism]], the practice of rituals.<ref>{{cite book |last=McKim |first=Donald K. |title=Westminster Dictionary of Theological Terms |publisher=Westminster John Knox Press |year=1996 |pages=197, 242 |isbn=978-0-664-25511-4}}</ref> The word is a [[neoclassical compound]]—{{lang|grc|ὀρθοπραξία}} (''orthopraxia'') meaning 'correct practice'.
While orthodoxies make use of codified beliefs, in the form of [[creed]]s, and ritualism more narrowly centers on the strict adherence to prescribed [[rite]]s or [[ritual]]s, orthopraxy is focused on [[Complex family|issues of family]], [[Cultural heritage|cultural integrity]], the transmission of [[tradition]], [[sacrifice|sacrificial offerings]], [[Ritual purity|concerns of purity]], [[ethical system]], and the enforcement thereof.<ref>{{cite book |last=Antes |first=Peter |author2=Armin W. Geertz |author3=Randi R. Warne |title=New Approaches to the Study of Religion: Regional, Critical, and Historical Approaches |volume=2 |publisher=Walter de Gruyter |year=2004 |pages=86 |isbn=978-3-11-018175-3}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://wordnet.princeton.edu/perl/webwn?s=ritualism |title=Ritualism |accessdate=September 10, 2008 |publisher=Princeton University |quote=(1) ''the study of religious or magical rites and ceremonies''; (2) ''exaggerated emphasis on the importance of rites or ritualistic forms in worship''}}{{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
Typically, traditional or [[folk religion]]s ([[paganism]], [[animism]]) are more concerned with orthopraxy than orthodoxy, and some{{Who|date=October 2017}} argue that equating the term "[[faith]]" with "[[religion]]" presents a [[Christian]]-[[bias]]ed notion of what the primary characteristic of religion is. This contrasts with the case of (for example) [[Hinduism]], in which orthopraxy and ritualism are not easily disentangled.
==Etymology== From the Greek ''orthos'' "straight" + ''praxis'' "action", first used in 1851,<ref>Shorter Oxford English Dictionary 3rd ed</ref> there are two versions of the term: "orthopraxis" and "orthopraxy".<ref>[[Oxford English Dictionary]]</ref> "Orthopraxy" is the older and more common term, and is parallel to "orthodoxy".
==Christianity== [[Image:Ten Commandments Monument.jpg|thumb|right|170px|A [[Ten Commandments#Christianity|Ten Commandments]] monument at the [[Texas State Capitol]]. <!-- Included is the commandment to "Remember the [[Sabbath in Christianity|Sabbath day]], to keep it holy". -->]] {{Main|Christian ethics|Good works}} {{See also|New Perspective on Paul}} Although traditionally Christianity is seen as primarily orthodoxical (as in the [[Nicene Creed]]'s "I believe in ..."), some [[Christian denominations]] and leaders today, from [[Roman Catholic]] to [[Evangelical Christian]]s, have started to describe their religions as both orthodoxical and orthopraxic. The premise is correct belief compels correct action, and incorrect action is caused by incorrect beliefs.<ref>{{cite book |last=Murphy |first=Francesca Aran |title=Christ the Form of Beauty: A Study in Theology and Literature |publisher=Continuum International Publishing Group |year=1995 |pages=150–151 |isbn=978-0-567-09708-8}}</ref><ref>''See also'': John 5:1–18; 8:13–19; 10:24–33; 11:45–54; 18–19:16 (Demonstrates how correct/incorrect belief causes correct/incorrect action from a biblical perspective.)</ref>
Taking this combination of "correct belief" and "correct action" a step further, [[prosperity theology]], found in charismatic and Pentecostal traditions, teaches correct religious belief and behavior receives material reward and physical healing, in addition to being a necessary component for accepting God's [[Divine grace|grace]]. Prosperity theology is a concept known as reciprocity when discussing traditional or ethnic religions such as that in [[Religion in ancient Greece|Ancient Greece]], but is limited to correct behavior over any one theological idea.<ref>{{cite book |last=Gill |first=Christopher |author2=Norman Postlethwaite |author3=Richard Seaford |title=Reciprocity in Ancient Greece |publisher=Oxford University Press |year=1998 |isbn=978-0-19-814997-2}}</ref>
The applicability of [[biblical law in Christianity]] is disputed. Most Christians believe that some or all of the [[Ten Commandments]] are still binding or have been reinstituted in the [[law of Christ]]. A minority of Christians are [[Mitzvah|Torah-observant]] and at the other extreme are [[Antinomianism#Antinomianism among Christians|antinomian]] and [[Christian anarchism|Christian anarchistic]] views.
===Eastern Christianity=== {{Main|Praxis (Byzantine Rite)}} {{See also|Orthodox Church}} Praxis is a key to understanding the [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] tradition, which is observed by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] and some [[Eastern Catholic Churches]]. This is because praxis is the basis of the understanding of faith and works as conjoint, without separating the two. The importance of praxis, in the sense of action, is indicated in the dictum of Saint [[Maximus the Confessor]]: "Theology without action is the theology of demons."<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=kF4cAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Theology+without+action+is+the+theology+of+demons%22&dq=%22Theology+without+action+is+the+theology+of+demons%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=C4mVVN-zNMvT7AafzoHoDg&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAw Virginia Fabella, Sergio Torres (editors), ''Doing Theology in a Divided World''] (Orbis Books 1985 {{ISBN|978-0-88344197-8}}), p. 15</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=_7VKAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA67 Paul W. Chilcote, ''Wesley Speaks on Christian Vocation''] (Wipf and Stock 2001 {{ISBN|978-1-57910812-0}}), p. 67</ref><ref>[http://www.edinburgh2010.org/fileadmin/files/edinburgh2010/files/docs/Mission%20among%20Other%20Faiths_Orthodox%20Perspective%20090820.doc Mission among Other Faiths: An Orthodox Perspective]</ref>
Union with [[God]], to which Christians hold that [[Jesus]] invited man, requires not just [[faith]], but correct practice of faith. This idea is found in the [[Biblical canon|Scriptures]] ([[First Epistle to the Corinthians|1 Cor]] [http://drbo.org/cgi-bin/d?b=drb&bk=53&ch=011&l=2 11:2], [[Second Epistle to the Thessalonians|2 Thes]] [http://drbo.org/cgi-bin/d?b=drb&bk=60&ch=002&l=14 2:14]) and the [[Church Fathers]], and is linked with the term ''praxis'' in Byzantine [[theology]] and vocabulary.[https://groups.yahoo.com/group/ortho-praxis/] In the context of Orthodoxy, praxis is mentioned opposite theology, in the sense of 'theory and practice'.[https://web.archive.org/web/20040606120041/http://arts.tuirgin.com/] Rather, it is a word that means, globally, all that Orthodox ''do''.[https://web.archive.org/web/20040808164646/http://www.orthodoxpraxis.org/article.php?id=2&menu=1] Praxis is 'living Orthodoxy'.[http://www.orthodoxinfo.com/praxis/rose_wv.aspx]
Praxis is perhaps most strongly associated with [[worship]]. "[[Orthopraxis]]" is said to mean "right glory" or "right worship"[http://www.orthodoxinfo.com/praxis/index.aspx]; only correct (or proper) practice, particularly correct worship, is understood as establishing the fulness glory given to God. This is one of the primary purposes of [[liturgy]] (divine labor), the work of the people. Some Byzantine sources maintain that in the [[Western Christianity|West]], Christianity has been reduced "to intellectual, ethical or social categories," whereas right worship is fundamentally important in our relationship to God, forming the faithful into the [[Body of Christ]] and providing the path to "true religious education."[https://web.archive.org/web/20070510124549/http://www.sf.goarch.org/religioused/TheOrthodoxDifference.htm] A "symbiosis of worship and work" is considered to be inherent in Byzantine praxis.[https://web.archive.org/web/20040702211116/http://www.syrianorthodoxarchdiocese.com/anagalpura.html]
==Hinduism== {{See also|Dharma}} {{unreferenced section|date=June 2018}} In the case of [[Hinduism]] orthopraxy and ritualism are conflated. Emphasis on ritual vs. personal salvation (''[[moksha]]'') was a major division in classical [[Hindu philosophy]], epitomized by [[Purva Mimamsa]] vs. [[Uttara Mimamsa]] (Vedanta).
Ritual (''[[Puja (Hinduism)|puja]]'') continues to play a central role in contemporary [[Hinduism]], but the enormous complexity of ancient ritual (''[[yajna]]'') only survives in a tiny minority of [[Shrauta]] practitioners. Even Hindus who diligently practice a subset of prescribed rituals are called orthoprax, to contrast them with other Hindus who insist on the importance of correct belief or understanding. The correctness of one's interpretation of the scripture is then considered less important than following traditions. For example, [[Srinivasa Ramanujan]] was a well-known example of an orthoprax Hindu.
In terms of "proper conduct" and other ethical precepts within the Hindu framework, the core belief involves the divinity of each individual soul (''[[jiva]]tma''). Each person harbors this "indwelling God (divinity)"; thus, conduct which unifies society and facilitates progress is emphasized. Self-centered existence is discouraged as a result of this ''jivatma'' concept. The Uttara Mimamsa philosophical school explicates this concept eloquently. Moreover, within the context of Uttara Mimamsa the role of ''[[Puja (Hinduism)|puja]]'' (ritual) also involves bringing the individual ''jivatma'' closer to the ''[[Paramatma]]'' (the Transcendent Divinity or God). Individuals who have attained this merging then become the spiritual guides to the community. Later developments within the Hindu religious and philosophic tradition thus try to unify these concepts of ritual, proper conduct, and personal salvation instead of leaving them in mutually conflicting terms. The movement inspired by [[Pandurang Shastri Athavale]] termed ''[[Swadhyaya]]'' seems to be one manifestation of this syncretism. However, other movements within the contemporary Hindu scene are also moving towards this union of external activity and internal development.
==Islam== {{See|Five Pillars of Islam}} Islam generally stresses orthopraxy over orthodoxy, but since the practice is held to come from doctrine, this is essentially orthodoxy applied to practice.
==Jainism== [[File:Karma AS.jpg|100px|thumb|left|[[Karma in Jainism|Karma]] as [[Action (philosophy)|action]] and reaction: if we sow [[Goodness and value theory|goodness]], we will reap goodness.]] {{See also|Jain philosophy}} [[Jain]] orthopraxy is based on two factors: [[Jain philosophy|Jain siddhanta]] (teachings of the [[Tirthankara]]) and ''kriya'' (practices prevalent at the time of the Tirthankaras). According to Jains, the Tirthankaras based their teachings and philosophy after knowing the realities on this universe (like ''[[Dravya (Jainism)|dravya]]'' and ''[[Tattva (Jainism)|tattva]]''). Based on these realities, they propounded true and eternal principles like ''ahimsa'', truth, karma etc. that govern the universe. Jain rituals were codified on the basis of these principles to give effect to the teachings of the Tirthankaras.
==Judaism== [[Image:OUKosher.JPG|thumb|175px|''The logo of a circle with a 'U' inside it (called: "O U")'' indicates this product is certified as [[kosher]] by the [[Orthodox Union]]. <!-- ''[[Pareve]]'' indicates that this product contains neither milk nor meat derived ingredients. -->]] [[Judaism]] attaches primary importance to the practice of the ''[[mitzvot]]'', and that each act of daily life comply with the ethical and ritual teachings of the [[Torah]]. However, these gestures are intended to be motivated by the system of values and ethics of which they are a part, so that orthodoxy is not seen as simply a way of thinking according to established dogmas.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Dubov|first1=Nissan Dovid|title=Doing or Understanding - Which Comes First?|url=http://www.chabad.org/library/article_cdo/aid/108401/jewish/Doing-or-Understanding.htm|website=chabad.org|accessdate=8 July 2014}}</ref>
[[File:Shema1j.ogg|thumb|left|Shema Yisrael (שמע ישראל) Recitation]] Moreover, [[Maimonides]] codifies his [[Jewish principles of faith#Maimonides' 13 principles of faith|13 principles of faith]] as a binding theological dogma, and according to Maimonides some laws of the [[Torah]] require the acceptance of certain basic beliefs, such as the first and second positive commandments in Maimonides' [[Sefer Hamitzvot]], which mandate the belief in God and his indivisible unity, or the recitation of the [[Shema]]. Maimonides' codification of [[Halakha|Jewish law]] even contains a section entitled ''Yesodei HaTorah'' which delineates the required beliefs of Judaism.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Maimonides|first1=Moses|title=Hilchot Yesodei HaTorah|url=http://www.chabad.org/library/article_cdo/aid/904959/jewish/Yesodei-haTorah.htm|website=Chabad.org|accessdate=8 July 2014}}</ref>
And yet, there is a small group of Jews in the orthodox world who argue that the nature of Judaism is orthoprax, such as [[Jeffrey Radon]], a teacher of Jewish studies who has an internet site Orthoprax Judaism devoted to Jewish studies in a democratic spirit,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.orthopraxjudaism.com|title=Home Page - Orthoprax Judaism|author=|date=|website=Orthoprax Judaism|accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref> and [[Israel Drazin]], a former army chaplain and [[rabbi]] who recently came out in support of the idea that the nature of Judaism is orthoprax.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://booksnthoughts.com/the-torah-requires-orthopraxy-not-orthodoxy/|title=The Torah requires orthopraxy not orthodoxy|author=|date=|website=booksnthoughts.com|accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref> Radon argues that Maimonides codification of principles of belief as a binding theological dogma was not only an innovation but a distortion of the ancient Jewish tradition based upon the Bible and the Talmud (and that Maimonides was aware that his codification of a binding dogma was a distortion, and he codified such a dogma only for the unlearned Jewish masses to strengthen them as Christians and Muslims had codified such dogma) as there is no binding theological dogma in the Bible or in the Talmudic literature (and fundamental beliefs of the Bible or Talmudic literature do not have the status of binding dogma), and the commandments of the Torah as the basis of Jewish law are according to Jewish tradition commandments of doing and not doing (and not of believing or not believing).
==Neopaganism== [[British Traditional Wicca]] is highly orthopraxic, with "traditions" (as denominations in [[Wicca]] are called) being precisely that—defined by what is traditionally done, rather than shared beliefs.<ref>SilverWitch, Sylvana (1995). [https://web.archive.org/web/20010412195549/http://widdershins.org/vol1iss3/l03.htm "A Witch in the Halls of Wisdom: Northwest Legend Fritz Muntean Discusses School, Theology, and the Craft"], in ''Widdershins'' Vol. 1, Issue 3 (Lammas 1995).</ref> Other [[Modern Paganism|Neopagans]] may or may not share this quality, as noted by [[James R. Lewis (scholar)|James R. Lewis]], who draws a distinction between "Religious Neo-Pagans" and "God/dess Celebrants." Lewis states the majority of the Neopagan movement is strongly opposed to Religionist traditions that incorporate any form of orthopraxy or orthodoxy.<ref>{{cite book |last=Lewis |first= James R. |title=Magical Religion and Modern Witchcraft |publisher=SUNY Press |year=1996 |pages=84–85 |isbn=978-0-7914-2889-4}}</ref> In fact, many Neopagan organizations, when discussing orthopraxy, limit themselves solely to ritualism.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.adf.org/articles/cosmology/discussing-pagan-theology.html |title=Discussing Pagan Theology |accessdate=September 10, 2008 |author=Corrigan, Ian |publisher=[[Ár nDraíocht Féin]] (A Druid Fellowship) |quote=''The pagan religion was about orthopraxy, doing the customs correctly. Your "believerhood" at a temple had more to do with entering the temple and walking three times about the idol and making your image and reciting the inscription on the wall, which was how they did it in the Roman temples.''}}</ref>
==Polytheistic Reconstructionism== {{See also|Polytheistic Reconstructionism}} Reconstructionist religions make full use of orthopraxy, defining their practices as a lifestyle, and identifying correct action as living life in accord with specific ideals and principles,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.asatru.org/ |title=Answers about Asatru |accessdate=September 11, 2008 |publisher=[[Asatru Alliance]] |quote=''Proper behavior in Asatru consists of maximizing one's virtues and minimizing one's vices.''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=An Introduction to Celtic Reconstructionist Paganism |url=http://paganachd.com/faq/ethics.html |accessdate=September 11, 2008 |publisher=Paganachd |quote=''(Celtic Recostructionism is) grounded in traditional Celtic virtues which should be embraced, adopted, and integrated into one’s daily life.''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.religioromana.net/about.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20031204235941/http://www.religioromana.net/about.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=December 4, 2003 |title=About the Religio Romana |accessdate=September 11, 2008 |publisher=Temple of Religio Romana |quote=''We have included the ancient Roman Virtues as an accompaniment to spiritual practice as we feel that they are conducive to the fulfillment of one's higher self.'' }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ysee.gr/index-eng.php?f=faq&type=english |title=Frequently asked questions about the Hellenic religion and tradition |accessdate=September 11, 2008 |publisher=Supreme Council of Ethnikoi Hellenes |quote=''We do not just strive for a superficial return to the 'ancient ways', but on the contrary, for the return of a different kind of person, Hellenic Man, who will be governed by humanistic values, as were first expressed and exhibited by our ancestors. A type of man who will journey on the path of Virtue.''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kemet.org/kemexp1.html |title=What is Kemetic Orthodoxy? |accessdate=September 11, 2008 |publisher=The House of Netjer |quote=''Practicing Kemetic Orthodoxy requires a commitment to preserving the cultural heritage established in the past which Kemetic Orthodoxy continues to represent, even in places and times well removed from its original practice.'' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080911234223/http://www.kemet.org/kemexp1.html |archivedate=September 11, 2008 |df= }}</ref> rather than focusing solely on ritual or promoting a single cosmology, metaphysical idea, or theological theory as absolute truth.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hellenismos.us/?p=124 |title=On Orthopraxy |accessdate=September 12, 2008 |author=Alexander, Timothy Jay |publisher=Hellenismos.us |quote=''Our concern is with humanity and the natural world, and we leave open questions relating to the absolute nature of the Gods, Absolute Reality, and Divine Truth to individual personal interpretation.''}}</ref>
==Taoism== [[Image:BRASILRIO4.jpg|thumb|right|[[Qigong]] practitioners in [[Brazil]]]] {{main|Taoism}} {{expand section|date=June 2018}}

{{Infobox single <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Songs --> | Name = Pants on the Ground | Cover = Pants on the Ground single.jpg | Cover size = | Border = | Alt = | Caption = | Artist = [[Larry Platt|"General" Larry Platt]] | Album = | A-side = | B-side = | Released = February 4, 2010 | Format = [[Music download|Digital download]] | Recorded = | Genre = [[Hip hop music|hip hop]], [[outsider music|outsider]] | Length = 3:30 | Label = [[American King Music]] | Writer = Larry Platt, Carlos Thornton | Producer = Los Vegaz | Certification = | Chronology = | Last single = | This single = | Next single = | Misc = }}
'''"Pants on the Ground"''' is a [[Novelty song|novelty]]/[[Protest song|protest]] song which, in 2010, became the first single that civil rights activist "General" [[Larry Platt]], who co-wrote it, released. The song is meant to protest the practice of [[Sagging (fashion)|sagging]]. It was released on American King Music on February 4, 2010. The song became an [[internet meme]] after being performed during the [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]] audition for ''[[American Idol]]'' that aired on January 13, 2010.
==Production== The song was first performed in 2001 by "General" Larry Platt in the streets of Atlanta during many campaigns for elected municipal officials across the city of Atlanta, and he had professionally recorded it as early as 2002. The "General" is also known for performing the song publicly in events and functions around the city of Atlanta including a live performance at the [[Sweet Auburn Heritage Festival]] in October 2009 and [[Centennial Olympic Park]] in 2008. Platt was encouraged to perform the song during the [[American Idol (season 9)|ninth ''American Idol'' season]] auditions by civil rights activist Sally Harley. After he performed the song in response to her encouragement, it gained popularity as a [[viral video|viral hit]].<ref name="MSN">{{cite news |url=http://tv.msn.com/superfans/reality-tv-competitions/blog/idol-s-most-loveable-rejects/?GT1=28153 |title="Idol's" Most Lovable Rejects |date=January 27, 2010 |publisher=''[[MSN]]'' |accessdate=February 16, 2010 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100131095948/http://tv.msn.com/superfans/reality-tv-competitions/blog/idol-s-most-loveable-rejects/?GT1=28153 |archivedate=January 31, 2010 |df= }}</ref> Platt's former manager Jason Mills released the studio version of the song, without Platt's consent.{{Citation needed|date=March 2012}} The single version of the song was released on February 4, 2010 by American King Music for [[MP3]] download where the song has reportedly sold more than 260,000 downloads.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.getyourpantsup.com |title=General Larry Platt "Pants On The Ground" |accessdate=February 16, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110128165844/http://getyourpantsup.com/ |archivedate=January 28, 2011 |df= }}</ref> Platt has been offered deals by several labels including Melee Entertainment, Jake Records and others have also entered negotiations with Larry Platt to produce a single of the hit song, but due to the unauthorized distribution of the song by [[American King Music]] it has been difficult to navigate.<ref>Inside Trademarks <http://insidetrademarks.com/2010/01/23/pants-on-the-ground-trademark-dispute-possible>, February 27, 2010.</ref> It was reported that Platt's former manager Jason Mills intended to promote the song servicing radio stations to gain exposure, which is a common music industry practice. Platt has since secured new management under a firm based in Atlanta headed up by Earl Little.
==Parodies== Several celebrities performed the song in the days that followed the original airing of Platt's audition. This included late night talk show host [[Jimmy Fallon]], who performed a version of the song while also impersonating [[Neil Young]] on his show ''[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]].''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/959718/jimmy-fallon-covers-pants-on-the-ground-as-neil-young |title=Jimmy Fallon Covers 'Pants on the Ground' As Neil Young |publisher=Billboard.com |date=2009-09-14 |accessdate=2012-08-29}}</ref> [[National Football League|NFL]] quarterback and Green Bay Packers legend, [[Brett Favre]], was also caught leading the [[Minnesota Vikings]] in a performance of the song in their locker room following their game against the [[Dallas Cowboys]] in the [[2009–10 NFL playoffs]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/01/17/brett-favre-pants-on-the_n_426500.html |title=Brett Favre 'Pants On The Ground' VIDEO: Singing QB Shocks Viewers |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= January 17, 2010|accessdate=2012-08-29 |first=Whitney |last=Snyder}}</ref> ''[[Today (NBC program)|Today Show]]'' hosts [[Meredith Vieira]], [[Matt Lauer]], [[Al Roker]] and [[Ann Curry]] also organized a performance of the song. [[Member of the Legislative Assembly#Canada|Canadian MLA]] [[T.J. Burke]] also performed a rendition of the song in criticizing Progressive Conservative opposition leader [[David Alward]] during a session of the [[New Brunswick]] provincial legislature. Platt himself made a subsequent appearance on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s ''[[The View (U.S. TV series)|The View]]'' on January 18, 2010, where he performed the song in its entirety. "Pants on the Ground" was also sung on [[World Wrestling Entertainment|WWE]]'s [[Royal Rumble 2010]] PPV event, in a backstage segment between [[Teddy Long]], [[Cryme Tyme]], [[Ranjin Singh]], and [[The Great Khali]]. [[Tyler Perry]], in character as [[Mabel Simmons|Mabel "Madea" Simmons]], performed the Madea remix to this song in the play ''[[Madea's Big Happy Family]],'' which he had written for the stage.
==Chart performances==
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Charts (2010)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://acharts.us/song/53497 |title=Chart Pos. Billboard.com |publisher=Acharts.us |date= |accessdate=2011-07-20}}</ref><ref>[http://www.billboard.com/#/song/general-larry-platt/pants-on-the-ground/17739555 Chart Pos. Billboard.com #song]</ref> ! Position |- | [[Canadian Hot 100]] | style="text-align:center;"|63 |- | US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] | style="text-align:center;"|46 |}
==Live performances== Platt performed the song outside the [[Grammys]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music/2010/01/29/2010-01-29_grammys_red_carpet_to_get_its_pants_on_the_ground__general_larry_platt_will_pefo.html | location=New York | work=Daily News | title=Grammys red carpet to get its 'Pants on the Ground' - General Larry Platt will perform [sic] 'Idol' hit | first=Sherryl | last=Connelly | date=January 29, 2010}}</ref>
The song was performed at the ''American Idol'' Finale by Platt, accompanied by [[William Hung]] and a crew of dancers who dropped their pants as part of the act.<ref>{{cite web|last=Young |first=John |url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2010/05/27/american-idol-finale-recap/ |title='American Idol': On the scene for the finale | PopWatch | EW.com |publisher=Popwatch.ew.com |date=2010-05-27 |accessdate=2011-07-20}}</ref>
During some concerts, Florida-based Christian rock band [[Among the Thirsty]] performs a verse from "Pants on the Ground" during the song "One Sound."
The song returned to ''American Idol'' on April 7, 2016 for a short moment during the series finale as an interjection performance while "[[No (Meghan Trainor song)|No]]" by [[Meghan Trainor]] was sung by other ''American Idol'' alumni.
